title: Professional Education & Further Development, Two Year College, Four Year College
subject: BIP for Meteorologists

82416FD2AF324516A9CE97F803EA6047.description: Explain the differences between climate models and those used for weather prediction, explain why there are uncertainties in climate predictions, describe how climate predictions can be verified, and explain why there are differences between statistical intra-annual forecasts and climate model predictions

CDA8F89F0B9E4D19BF9104EBCAB45E9F.description: Assess the major impacts of climate variability and change, and outline the adaptation and mitigation strategies that are applied in response to current and projected changes in the climate

82A43FBAD1D944B9991B67B6FB61F7CD.description: Apply physical and dynamical reasoning to explain the causes of externally-forced climate change (including the influence of human activity), and the source of uncertainty in understanding these causes

A45C170F88F24A979AC0B5688DD8BA28.description: Apply physical and dynamical reasoning to explain the causes of internally-generated climate variability (including examples of teleconnections, anomalies, and the climatic effects of major regimes such as the Madden-Julian Oscillation, North Atlantic Oscillation, and El Niño-Southern Oscillation)

97CEA1852319433994E32407A045CA23.description: Describe the various ways in which the atmosphere influences the oceans and the oceans influence the atmosphere

9E4B922FF8FA43B5B36BF83657A073BC.description: Describe how the climate has changed in the recent past in the context of changes that have occurred more generally in the past and the techniques used for attributing the causes

E4183A3B64E04439A9C5C2CC6B1B659A.description: Describe the source and processing of data that is used to reconstruct past climates and assess changes in climate and atmospheric composition

DBDD8DBBD6214D4B99AA6923E379BC52.description: Describe the key products and services based on climate information that are provided to the public and other users, describe their inherent uncertainties and how the products and services are used (for example, for decision-making and managing risk)

DF634922FB104CEF9B1882246D965ACF.description: Describe the climatology and seasonal changes of the region of responsibility and the way climatological information can be obtained and displayed

58EE27C242C9492FB0612EB9DB262A48.description: Describe the techniques for classifying the climate, the principles behind these techniques, and the meaning and use of standard statistical variables used to describe climate

5FFDAD8B8AA84A8A9043BD6FBED8C7C7.description: Assess the factors that determine regional and local climates

B37BBF5A4E5E42E391D13CFE47CD4E0A.description: Explain the main features of the global circulation of the atmosphere and oceans based on an understanding of the physical and dynamical process that are involved, and describe the global energy balance and the role of the atmosphere and oceans in balancing the radiative heating differences between the equator and pole

931112D94E8F46428E783FED2C0B4D1A.description: Describe the main features of the energy cycle, hydrological cycle, carbon cycle and nitrogen cycle

2068E86EDE864108AF2F491E72FBCF7D.description: Describe how climate is measured and the uncertainty inherent in climate data, how climate data is analysed using statistics, and how climate can be measured using remote sensing

794A7521411B48C3BD2CFCC76D89FEAC.description: Describe climate and how it differs from weather

96FD03EB11AA4D898396060FF086176B.description: Describe the key components of the Earth system (i.e., atmosphere, oceans, land, cryosphere and solid earth)

FAA53065BB3D46908BB4F81A474DE8D8.description: Global Circulation, Climates and Climate Services

4411ECEAEB524A95A4A473A498F0DC76.description: Identify the economic and social impacts of meteorological services upon a country and their key user sectors.

C272257B74C942C39288EA174E565CBB.description: Explain the basic techniques used to assess the quality of products and services

6CF4C5AD1F4F4C5EA9B0739F2FBCE9B5.description: Describe the extent to which hazardous weather systems affecting the region of responsibility can be forecast, and explain the importance of assessing the risk of hazardous weather, issuing prompt and accurate warnings, and of understanding the potential impact of hazardous weather on society

F0CD2F74201A4847B2ABDFB5007C1B1E.description: Describe the key products and services, including warnings of hazardous weather conditions, based on current and forecast weather information, that are provided to the public and other users, and describe how the products and services are used (for example, for decision-making and managing risk)

C6B3FA6EC2074AA482DFE8A75D65B88E.description: Communicate weather information, orally or in written form using deterministic and probabilistic approaches, that meets user requirements

F880E126CF61477A8CD700AFE8B71055.description: Describe the function of National Meteorological Services in monitoring and forecasting the weather and the role of other service providers

F0D2C0B15A0246BE8B6CF9B3F2488A39.description: Combine information from various sources to explain the current weather conditions, and use basic forecasting techniques, including the interpretation of NWP output, to forecast atmospheric variables (for example, maximum and minimum temperature, wind, and precipitation type and intensity) at a specific location

1ED16FBE64624F31AF04D928A7CFB546.description: Apply conceptual models in making short-range forecasts and interpreting longer- range forecasts

B5E4076B1A164625B55E8B74A1E80E5B.description: Explain the advantages and disadvantages of preparing forecasts based on persistence, extrapolation and numerical weather prediction (NWP), and describe the role of the forecaster

310AFD37F4094670996B4E66E1A886BF.description: Describe the main components of the forecast process, including observation, analysis, diagnosis, prognosis, product preparation, product delivery and product verification

2006968626FC4A52988F1F151E0E7474.description: Describe factors affecting local weather (for example, the effect of orography and large bodies of water on cloud and precipitation, or the effect of land surface types)

66C3C60D79A648A8807CA4D2753BD142.description: Describe the role of international collaboration in the making and sharing of observations, with emphasis on the World Weather Watch, WMO Global Observing System and WMO Information System (including the Global Telecommunications System)

CE29F4C39CE045A88950044412909125.description: Integrate remote-sensing data and synoptic observations to identify synoptic and mesoscale systems and diagnose the weather situation through relating features found in radar and satellite imagery to features observed from other data sources

98AC02DD8C834518BFFA915DA1F144C8.description: Interpret satellite images, including use of common wavelengths (infrared, visible, water vapour and near infrared) and enhancements and animated imagery, to identify cloud types and patterns, synoptic and mesoscale systems, and special features (fog, sand, volcanic ash, dust, fires, etc.)

941A6DD431284E518DD47DCB6BDF42DD.description: Interpret common radar displays, including use of enhancements and animated imagery, to identify features associated with convective and mesoscale processes

30249F1A533F427CA4135DE814192C0A.description: Analyse and interpret synoptic charts and soundings plotted on a thermodynamic diagram, and describe the limitations of the observations used in the analyses

BAE97763BB6B4553910B13486F3A58B3.description: Describe how observations are quality-controlled, coded and distributed

DE685731F1894372AA6741FD83C776F0.description: Monitor the weather, make a basic surface observation using remote and directly-read instruments and visual assessments (including identifying cloud types, cloud amount and weather type), explain the reasons for the visual assessments, and explain the underlying causes of a variety of weather phenomena that are visible from the Earth's surface

2702108CA46248EF8022E63C9F6BAE68.description: Analyse recent and/or historic weather events to assess the extent to which theories and conceptual models of convective and mesoscale phenomena resemble reality

11A9FCE573DA42A2A36953F18B15CCAD.description: Describe the weather, with emphasis on any extreme or hazardous conditions that might be associated with convective and mesoscale phenomena, and the likely impact of such conditions

3A41BBC724C24765B94BE70CBFFE7F78.description: Apply physical and dynamical reasoning to explain the structure and formation of orographic mesoscale phenomena (lee waves, rotors, up-slope and down-slope winds, valley winds, gap flows, lee lows, etc.)

6A4B693F1A1846EB996D128AC998967D.description: Apply physical and dynamical reasoning to explain the structure and formation of mesoscale convective systems;

B6A11D02D92042608F653BAE55FDC715.description: Apply physical and dynamical reasoning to explain the structure and formation of isolated convective systems such as thunderstorms and convective storms (including single cell, multicell and supercell storms)

71B0B9233120403C8501FD8D1914DFF7.description: Apply physical and dynamical reasoning to explain the structure and formation of mesoscale gravity waves

22287D71E0FE4B7F9339F53A56F3B945.description: Explain the mesoscale features associated with depressions (rainbands, drylines, gust fronts, squall lines, etc.)

D6ED50A098824A4F8283295ACD00FF57.description: Describe the space and time scales associated with mesoscale phenomena, and the differences in the dynamical processes that drive mesoscale and synoptic scale systems

42F4337AA5DE440B8F3301C961D04B80.description: Analyse recent and/or historic weather events to assess the extent to which theories and conceptual models of tropical systems resemble reality

B6B1C5C0821D47CBB7F2084283B784D2.description: Describe the weather, with emphasis on any extreme or hazardous conditions that might be associated with tropical weather systems (including tropical cyclones and monsoons) and the likely impact of such conditions

13E639DDD46945FEA2B7F719E6A2C3E0.description: Describe the role of ocean-atmosphere coupling with emphasis on the theoretical basis and impact of El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO)

99BC5A1EAF23439BA036E3E2DC6A465A.description: Apply physical and dynamical reasoning to explain the structure and characteristics of monsoons and the main dynamical processes involved in their development

2200A8DBB68842A19721E202388432C3.description: Apply physical and dynamical reasoning to explain the structure and characteristics of tropical cyclones, the main dynamical processes involved in their development, and the techniques used to forecast the development and evolution of tropical storms

2F6C79C0117343298CCD856354C39AD4.description: Describe the various types of tropical wave (including Kelvin waves, equatorial Rossby waves and Madden-Julian Oscillation) and their relationship to organized convection and cyclogenesis

4D29AE8FC3BD459FB9A749FF13E4C314.description: Explain how tropical weather systems differ from those in mid-latitudes and polar regions

E68CD34399D94950A9F4CB9615F52EEB.description: Describe the techniques used to analyse tropical flows, including the depiction of streamlines and isotachs, and the identification of areas of convergence/divergence

7C316FD703C741759297182E5FED34D5.description: Describe the main tropical disturbances and their temporal variability, including the ITCZ, tropical waves, trade inversions, trade winds, tropical/sub-tropical jet streams, cloud clusters, squall lines, tropical depressions, sub-tropical ridges and upper-level anticyclones

4AF275DE86824E0D8C16A2E66269F57F.description: Describe the general circulation in the tropics and its seasonal variation in terms of the temperature, zonal wind, meridional motions, humidity and sea-level pressure

D5C24982DF9F48D2B24C8DAD16420E8E.description: Analyse recent and/or historic weather events to assess the extent to which theories and conceptual models of mid-latitude and polar weather systems resemble reality

6C56EE3A8ECB4F5AA10B0DCDE7D02B68.description: Describe the weather, with emphasis on any extreme or hazardous conditions, that might be associated with mid-latitude and polar weather systems and the likely impact of such conditions

0EB4ABBA07AD4FE78EA6918E42377206.description: Explain the characteristics and formation of polar weather systems, including katabatic winds, barrier winds and polar lows

E1E67D8583A84A19BAF3316CF127F43F.description: Explain the structure and dynamical characteristics of fronts, the relationship between frontogenesis and vertical motion, and the processes causing upper-level frontogenesis

610746B5B3A448AAB1CE847C52AD8CE0.description: Apply knowledge of dynamical processes to explain cyclogenesis and the factors contributing to explosive cyclogenesis

BE360D8B89FA4D82B4CE2EDF2777899A.description: Diagnose synoptic-scale vertical motion in mid-latitude weather systems (for example, by considering ageostrophic motion, using the Petterssen or Sutcliffe Development Theory or applying the omega equation)

08BC097FD5CF49938284D1D21B1A044B.description: Apply physical and dynamical reasoning to explain the development, structure and impact of jet streaks and the relationship between the jet stream and the development of mid-latitude depressions

D2E5DE52CA3E4688ABF8D404FCF42C37.description: Apply physical and dynamical reasoning to explain the life cycle of mid-latitude depressions in terms of the Norwegian cyclone model, including the three-dimensional structure of a developing depression and the air flow through the depression

A299FD548BD34C7E99624B6EEF241F0A.description: Use knowledge of physical processes to describe the characteristics of warm, cold and stationary and occluded fronts, how these fronts are related to synoptic fields, and the three- dimensional nature of frontal boundaries

5198EBA850024EB1B90CABDEFA248340.description: Modification of bodies of air: Explain how bodies of air can be modified by the environment, the resulting characteristics of the air, and the ways in which the modifications can affect weather at distant locations through air movement

3CECB24D01024CAC87A84A57FA6CDAC8.description: Explain how mid-latitude and polar weather systems differ from those in the tropics

F7BB3C9F20F5497581A036D1604F5A68.description: Describe the techniques used for post-processing NWP output (for example, use of model output statistics) and some of the applications driven by NWP output (for example, wave and crop yield models)

96622214ED30484A8F34562A8C0371C0.description: Describe the techniques used to provide detailed regional atmospheric information based on the output from global models

BBBF2DEB3CEE45A7BA67B407D4CDDC9C.description: Explain the scientific basis of monthly, seasonal and intra-annual forecasting

0A010DB3F7334F9CB68CCEB33683CB60.description: Describe the principles behind ensemble forecasting and how such an approach can be used for short-, medium- and long-range forecasting

E0842A73A5D4467ABF3A02D4FFBA7B66.description: Assess the strengths and weaknesses of NWP and the reasons why there are limits to atmospheric predictability

8B75CC5483B14233BCC0F385A62D7AE0.description: Describe the key components of an NWP model (including the prognostic variables, physical laws, and how physical processes are parameterized), and explain the difference between types of models (for example, spectral versus grid-point and hydrostatic versus non-hydrostatic models)

26A292D6D3DE4D25B99DC4A61CC5D201.description: Explain how information from observing networks and systems is obtained and prepared for use in an NWP model, and explain the principles behind objective analysis, data assimilation (including 3D-Var and 4D-Var) and initialization

87C3C69CD4774F74A81CCAD791F956E0.description: Explain the conceptual model used to describe baroclinic and barotropic instability

58FDB2EAB97040EFADC2A07068B4A3C7.description: Use approximate forms of the equations describing fluid flows to describe the structure and propagation of sound waves, gravity waves and Rossby waves

97C6D7F911244411AE17352F541A53FA.description: Explain the approximations and assumptions involved in deriving the quasi- geostrophic system of equations, outline the derivation of the geopotential tendency and omega equations, provide a physical interpretation of the forcing terms in these equations, and use these equations to explain the distribution of vertical motion and geopotential tendency in a developing baroclinic system

DC52FE08B0484939911FE5D5A0BD1E8A.description: Explain the concepts of divergence, vorticity and potential vorticity, describe the mechanisms for generating changes in these parameters, and determine the relationship between divergence in the horizontal wind and vertical motion

6A220D2EBE004EC6B21C80944EA91E14.description: Use the equations of motion to explain the causes and implications of ageostrophic flow, including the effect of friction

238C16E7F85047BD89E70128D893B69D.description: Apply scale analysis to determine the dominant processes operating in various examples of fluid flows, and derive the equations describing balanced flows (including inertial, cyclostrophic, geostrophic and gradient flows), hydrostatic equilibrium and thermal wind balance

F9AF1E1CB50A4D7C95EEDC119408DBBD.description: Cast in pressure coordinates the primitive equations that govern the evolution of large-scale atmospheric flows, and state the advantages of using this coordinate system

488BB03A25B9448B8CEDCC8E1EDA0098.description: Explain the physical principles underlying the equations that describe large-scale atmospheric flows (i.e., the primitive equations), including deriving the apparent and real forces acting on a fluid in a rotating frame of reference, and formulating the horizontal equation of motion;

24F68D920E1246A8A5F435858261B204.description: Explain how aircraft, ships and buoys can be used to obtain atmospheric and oceanic information using remote-sensing systems

B94C38EB983B4F6D961CE90023358B08.description: Explain the physical principles behind weather radar, including pulsed-Doppler radar, signal characteristics, how the radar information is processed, and the effect of meteorological factors on the propagation and attenuation of radar waves in the atmosphere

2FA3488C9DC24F1F9E76FA766BC3B364.description: Describe the orbital characteristics, accuracy, sampling limitations, use and limitations of various satellite sounding systems

F3E345086DE24EE089812B9471575325.description: Explain how active sensing systems, such as radar, LIDAR and SODAR, are used to provide quantitative and qualitative information about atmospheric parameters such as temperature, humidity, cloud, precipitation (rate and type), wind speed and direction, turbulence and phenomena such as thunderstorms, microburst and tornadoes

74969E1E424149FFA46A50C9A3AB4C2E.description: Explain how passive sensing systems are used to provide digital data (such as visible, near infrared, infrared and water vapour imagery channels) and derived information about surface temperature and lightning, and atmospheric properties (including temperature, humidity, wind and atmospheric constituents)

30937EB5AEC841CAA835211AA3A954AD.description: Describe the principles behind the radiation measurements used for passive and active remote sensing, and how usable information can be derived from remote-sensing data, including the limitations and sources of errors/uncertainty

5B77E6570D31412E89D69ACE0E5EB432.description: Describe the uses of conventional observations and their limitations

E0B4A9B5DDB143C19C2FEA0F8EB94B16.description: Explain the importance of national and international standards of measurement, and compliance with best practice for the accurate calibration of instruments

1752BCB0F4764CF48DD149D8E0461EF8.description: Explain the common sources of error and uncertainty in standard instruments and observing techniques, the methods of estimating the confidence in a particular measurement, and the need to take account of the representativeness of an observation

8B30EC312DDA4877B00E4F62152B32E0.description: Describe, compare and contrast the characteristics of various instruments used to make surface and upper-air measurements of atmospheric parameters

6FEFB7AD283C4595B6C346414CCBD954.description: Explain the physical principles used in instruments to make upper-air measurements of geographical position, pressure, temperature, moisture and wind as well as ozone and other atmospheric constituents (for example, dust and volcanic ash)

4344634AF65A40E6A0AAA0CC188D1081.description: Explain the physical principles used in instruments to make surface measurements of temperature, moisture, pressure, precipitation, wind, cloud height, visibility, sunshine and radiation, and wave height, and the limitations and sensitivities of those instruments, and describe the way cloud and weather types are classified

CCB2F27AD51940DB81183F2EC8579BCF.description: Describe the common contaminants and pollutants affecting air quality and their major sources and sinks, along with their measurement, behaviour (including chemical and photochemical reactions and dry and wet deposition), and dispersion in the boundary layer, and explain how meteorological conditions, including stability, affect air quality, visibility and the dispersion of plumes

B61AB719F4B544648AA8D900C0C5976F.description: Describe the techniques used to measure boundary-layer properties, including air quality

8C1B54C7CC4F4DCE9C1641FF242D39B5.description: Explain how K theory is used to modify the equations of motion to take account of turbulence, explain the origin and significance of the Ekman spiral, and derive an expression for the vertical structure of the wind in the surface layer using the mixing-length hypothesis

9D50FCE59AE04968BDD9527B968742A6.description: Explain the impact on boundary layer flows of the terrain, coastline and urban areas, including thermally induced circulations (for example, sea and land breezes, lake effects and valley winds)

5A52E33E38D044A79D933610DFDDFAE1.description: Use knowledge of turbulence and surface energy exchanges to explain the typical profiles of meteorological variables in stable, neutral and unstable conditions

C6836096B8DD48BA86F7D1AA1B5BEF3D.description: Use knowledge of turbulence and surface energy exchanges to explain the evolution and diurnal variation of the boundary layer, with emphasis on the conductive transfer from the underlying surface and the role of radiative transfer in determining the behaviour of the boundary layer

001425D8F57D4515989C0C0B719F24A7.description: Describe the energy budget near the Earth's surface and explain the energy exchange processes in the surface layer

AEBDB9918DA845C7ACE6D2C7EE955821.description: Describe the fundamental turbulent processes in the atmospheric boundary, including laminar and turbulent flows, mechanisms for generating turbulence, dissipation, decomposition of the fields into mean and fluctuating parts, statistical description of turbulence, and turbulent transport of mass, heat, moisture and momentum

DC84C4258C18493B9A1FF39E6E8075A4.description: Describe the synoptic and mesoscale conditions and local processes that produce the various cloud types, precipitation types, icing, dew, frost and the various types of fog

1B6E7B944A284F6498630BAF6D43B3E1.description: Explain the mechanisms causing electrical phenomena that occur in the atmosphere (for example, cloud-to-ground and cloud-to-cloud lightning), and describe the meteorological conditions favourable for their occurrence

4D5116AC314840CCAC19933355423250.description: Describe and explain the microphysical processes leading to the formation and dissipation of cloud droplets, the growth and dissipation of warm and cold clouds, and the formation and growth of rain and solid precipitation particles, and describe the macroscopic structure of warm and cold clouds

5791B11B709046AC81C5471B8556A54D.description: Use a thermodynamic diagram to analyse atmospheric processes, including assessing atmospheric stability, determining common parameters used to describe the state of the atmosphere (including cloud parameters), and interpreting the key features of a sounding

DCF16B2399EF46418372E83CD488AE88.description: Explain the basic features of a stable, neutral, conditionally unstable, potentially unstable and unstable atmosphere, identify the environmental conditions that can produce various stabilities, and explain the physical basis of commonly used stability parameters

A4B59B27658641D7BAC1C647958B8EED.description: Define the parameters used to represent the amount of moisture in the atmosphere, explain their physical meaning, how they are related and how they are measured, explain the change of phase process, and determine the effect of water on the thermodynamic processes within the atmosphere

D0206734569D4D9B99262CC37FA5CD72.description: Apply the Laws of Thermodynamics, with emphasis on understanding the concept of an air parcel, describing adiabatic processes and deriving dry and saturated adiabatic lapse rates and the associated conserved quantities

0CF0191C1C494EC493D30CD7CCE5E2D8.description: Explain the transparency of the atmosphere and the origins of common optical phenomena (rainbows, haloes, coronas, sky colour, cloud colour, etc.) and describe the meteorological conditions favourable for their occurrence

DBEA8996DE2448E3982C4B9A86E39B93.description: Relate the Earth's climate and its latitudinal and temporal variation to the energy balance at the Earth's surface, variations in the solar flux and the Earth's orbital characteristics

EC77EE1AB6074133A9FE42E0333D31F8.description: Use a basic knowledge of radiative transfer theory to explain the effect of surface conditions (including snow and ice) and atmospheric constituents (including aerosols, water vapour, clouds, greenhouse gases and reactive gases) on the incoming and outgoing radiation

5E09562AEF63426B8510ADD9A684827D.description: Explain the composition of the atmosphere, including trace gases, aerosols, dust and volcanic ash, and pollutants

A5CCA5E9198D4B478FB10E1B2BB7CC78.description: Describe the vertical structure of the atmosphere in terms of its constituents, temperature and moisture content

229B950F53564393BE496704473F7FF7.description: Atmospheric Composition, Radiation and Optical Phenomena

084FD103E2E94C43BA202439E7C0B885.description: Create, publish and update a basic webpage

CE4DBF23D7C444C58258DA7952388A66.description: Discuss the components and functionality of a GIS, describe the potential uses of a GIS along with its benefits and shortcomings, and outline data quality issues involved in using a GIS

D5EBBD216D3542E3A380E1055BAF86A0.description: Find meteorological information using libraries, databases and internet searches;

895EB43569744BFE83880B7649EB27F9.description: Perform data processing and statistical analysis using spreadsheets and databases

B46AC983ABE74B77997646AA41B297ED.description: Use basic computer programming principles, and construct a simple computer programme for analysing or displaying data

89B6F5636B3043C39E1B7C5850B22CD7.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the different roles and functions in a team

09E90005FD424CD2BE69A7E00C6EBDF9.description: Make presentations within specified time limits, in which the content and style of delivery accurately conveys information in a way that can be understood by the audience

75E60005640D4D81A05C4C7824097833.description: Prepare written communications within specified time limits in a concise, accurate and comprehensible way, including use of word processing and presentation programmes

069975F7441141CC8FB637D19A86CABA.description: Describe the major cycles of the biosphere (with emphasis on the carbon and water cycle) and the influence of human activity on those cycles (for example, destruction of rain forests and melting of permafrost)

1004FCCCD30747CCA69A97C92B31A632.description: Describe the main geographical characteristics of the region of responsibility, including local terrain and local demographics, and describe map projections commonly used in meteorology

0EEE5A49006A4B789743E50951CDB997.description: Describe the hydrological cycle, explain the factors determining runoff, groundwater and surface water resources and the water balance, describe how hydrological measurements are made (precipitation, evaporation, soil moisture, river flow, groundwater, etc.), and identify the causes of different types of flooding

B868312B26D147FDAF4005C80E55AADE.description: Describe the general circulation and thermal structure of the oceans, explain the dynamical processes involved in producing ocean currents, tides and waves, and describe how measurements of temperature and salinity are taken

D9ED878B020046EE86BDEF78EFB6216F.description: Explain, using chemical nomenclature where appropriate, the basic concepts used in physical chemistry (including elements, molecules, compounds, bonds, chemical reactions and reaction rates), and describe the properties of gases and the key chemical reactions and cycles affecting the chemistry of the troposphere and stratosphere

311F93C41DD1403E852AE9DFECAD4F2D.description: Outline the scientific and technological advances that have contributed to the development of meteorology and its applications

BADD049FE561485EB101727BB0217E4B.description: Explain the fundamentals of electromagnetic radiation, including the electromagnetic spectrum, black body radiation, Planck's Law, Wien's Law and Stefan-Boltzmann Law, and scattering, absorption and emission of radiation

899423D89D6C4A43956362C14615B92F.description: Explain the concepts of reflection, refraction, diffraction and scattering of light

580A5AC796374B93968D66EA90C0EFAD.description: Explain the fundamentals of wave motion, including the concepts of reflection, refraction and diffraction, phase and group velocities, wave dispersion and wave breaking

4896738523F7444CADC74472D0E0D073.description: Apply the fundamentals of thermodynamics to gaseous systems, including the gas laws for dry and moist air, First and Second Laws of Thermodynamics, Dalton's Law and the kinetic theory of gases, and explain the physical basis of sensible heat, specific heat, latent heat, vapour pressure and saturation, reversible and irreversible processes, entropy and enthalpy, and the phases of water and the changes of phase

F6496943907447E8BF2D90EDA514C835.description: Explain the physical basis of heat transfer via conduction, convection and radiation

BB3ECFBB492142F4BF6C537609B120AE.description: Explain the basic kinematics of fluids, including the concepts of vorticity, divergence, deformation, streamfunction and velocity potential, and the relationship between streamlines and trajectories

A954C5E379B84827BC74C483FABFAE56.description: Apply the fundamentals of mechanics to bodies in motion, including Newton's laws of motion, equilibrium conditions, conservation of momentum and angular momentum, conservation of energy, the effects of rotating systems, and the relationship between Eulerian and Lagrangian frames of reference

D76CB34A4ADC4F56B1DEDA67CAB1BF57.description: Use basic numerical schemes for time and space derivatives and perform a basic stability analysis based on an understanding of the fundamental concepts and methods associated with numerical modelling

34046C348DD244BEA9A699AAF7B68FF7.description: Select suitable ways of displaying statistical data, calculate basic statistical indicators (for example, mean, standard deviation and test of significance), and draw conclusions from statistical data based on an understanding of the fundamental concepts and methods associated with probability theory and statistics

ADC58775C3A64615A7970B1FC1BA79A4.description: Perform algebraic manipulation on basic first- and second-order ordinary differential and partial differential equations, including use of Fourier series and verification of solutions, and identify initial-value and boundary-value problems

6243992693FD4CB49670572993614F63.description: Solve simultaneous equations, find eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix, and carry out calculations and transformations using complex numbers and vectors based on an understanding of the fundamental concepts and methods associated with matrices, vectors and complex numbers

B99D703AA7054DFD8853187FCD1CF7C4.description: Differentiate and integrate basic functions, find maxima and minima, and use a Taylor expansion based on an understanding of the fundamental concepts and methods in differential and integral calculus
